awd_titl_txt: Belmont Forum Collaborative Research: Pan-Arctic Options: Holistic Integration for Arctic Coastal-Marine Sustainability
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports U.S. researchers participating in a project competitively selected by a 14-country initiative on global change research through the Belmont Forum.  This multilateral initiative is designed to support research projects that utilize existing Arctic observing systems, datasets and models to evaluate key sustainability challenges and opportunities in the Arctic region, to innovate new sustainability science theory and approaches to these challenges and opportunities, and support decision-making towards a sustainable Arctic environment.  The funds requested will be used to support U.S. participants to cooperate in consortia that consist of partners from at least three of the participating countries and that bring together natural scientists, social scientists and research users (e.g., policy makers, regulators, NGOs, communities and industry).  Participants from other countries are funded through their national funding organizations.  

The Arctic Ocean is experiencing an environmental state-change with expanding human activities ranging from commercial shipping and energy development to ship-based tourism. Accordingly, with involvement of indigenous peoples, Arctic and non-Arctic states have begun to develop national and international management regimes to address emerging issues, impacts and resources in the Arctic Ocean. In every case, there will be challenges to implement agreements in the face of political and financial constraints. "Pan-Arctic Options - Holistic Integration for Arctic Coastal-Marine Sustainability" is designed in an international, interdisciplinary and inclusive manner, involving cost-effective collaboration with currently funded projects to contribute to informed decision-making by policy makers from government and industry. The core team includes natural and social scientists from Canada, China, France, Norway, Russia and the United States who will integrate document collections, geospatial data and stakeholder perspectives. This integrated decision-support tool will involve users in the co-design and co-production of options for both policy and built elements that are needed together for sustainable infrastructure development in the Arctic Ocean. A unique observational contribution from Pan-Arctic Options will be the analysis of Automatic Identification System (AIS) data of ship traffic across the Arctic Ocean collected from polar-orbiting satellites from 2009 forward. Results will be disseminated via journals (e.g., Science, Nature) and books as well as less-conventional methods involving facilitated dialogues in annual venues (e.g., Arctic Frontiers, Arctic Circle) and in the 2016 Arctic Expedition Summit involving the National Geographic Society and Google Ocean program. Management of this holistic project will be in the hands of a Steering Committee and an international Advisory Board involving global thought leaders and organizations (e.g., Arctic Monitoring and Assessment Programme), contributing to Arctic Ocean sustainability on a pan-Arctic scale.

Pan-Arctic Options: Holistic Integration for Arctic Coastal-Marine Sustainability (Award 1611241 / 213490) was an international, transdisciplinary and inclusive (holistic) project funded through the Belmont Forum with collaborators building common interests in Canada, China, France, Norway, Russia and United States from 2015-2022.   Pan-Arctic Options was intertwined with Arctic Options: Holistic Integration for Arctic Coastal-Marine Sustainability, funded in parallel through the Arctic Science, Engineering and Education for Sustainability program at the National Science Foundation (NSF) with the French National Centre for Scientific Research from 2013-2019.  The integrated goals, objectives and frameworks of these two coupled projects (Table 1: Intertwined Projects) enabled synergies with research into action (Figure 1: Informed Decisionmaking Pyramid).  The nonprofit Science Diplomacy Center is a legacy outcome, building on more than one hundred publications and presentations with ten co-investigators and three post-doctoral fellows, collaborating with nearly seventy institutions from ten US states and more than twenty countries (as recorded across the annual NSF reports).

      The apex goal of Pan-Arctic Options was to improve decisionmaking tools and methods with sustainable development as a common Arctic issue, emphasized by the 1996 Ottawa Declaration that established the Arctic Council.  This Pan-Arctic project was framed around options (without advocacy) that can be used or ignored explicitly, in contrast to recommendations that involve advocacy and often-polarizing agendas, leading to significant results with circumpolar as well as global relevance:

  1. 1.    Informed decisionmaking as the engine of science diplomacy from research into action;
  2. 2.    Analytical innovations with holistic integration of big data; and
  3. 3.    Common-interest building to support sustainable development with inclusion (who, what, when, where, why and how).

     Convening the 1st International Dialogue on Science and Technology Advice in Foreign Ministries in 2016 with diplomats from 23 foreign ministries led to the concept of an informed decision (operating across a continuum of urgencies short-to-long term).  The following year, applying the 2017 Agreement on Enhancing International Scientific Cooperation, a policy forum in Science magazine propelled science diplomacy with theory, methods and skills of informed decisionmaking.  The cross-cutting outcome goes to the heart of sustainable development with inclusion to enhance and couple:

  • Governance Mechanisms (laws, agreements and policies as well as regulatory strategies, including insurance, at diverse jurisdictional levels); and
  • Built Infrastructure (fixed, mobile and other assets, including communication, research, observing, information and other systems that require technology plus investment).

Significant progress with Pan-Arctic Options is reflected at a high-level by three published Springer books (Figure 2: Three Books), including the first two volumes in the INFORMED DECISIONMAKING FOR SUSTAINABILITY book series with the third volume in progress on Pan-Arctic Coupling of Governance and Infrastructure.

     As a direct outcome of Pan-Arctic Options, science diplomacy is now being trained across the United Nations and with the diplomatic corps of many nations through their foreign ministries as well as through universities, including the University of the Arctic, which initiated a Science Diplomacy Thematic Network in 2018.  Connecting dots, the February-March 2022 webinar series through the UN on Enhancing International Scientific Cooperation: Arctic Science and Technology Advice with Ministries enabled Open Science with inclusion before-through-after the inflection point of the Russian invasion of Ukraine.  That holistic dialogue is memorialized with the Science Diplomacy Action series that emerged with Pan-Arctic Options as well as the invited Nature Correspondence that Science Diplomacy Maintains Russia Co-Operation.

     Conceptualization of an ecopolitical region, in contrast to a geopolitical region, further influenced analytical innovations with Pan-Arctic Options across the data-evidence interface (Figure 1) with the oldest continuous Satellite Automatic Identification System (S-AIS) record of maritime ship traffic north of the Arctic Circle.  These unique big data, involving more than 173,000,000 S-AIS records from 2009-2018, have been preserved with the Arctic Data Center.  Next-generation Arctic marine shipping assessments with S-AIS data (Table 2: Next-Generation AMSA) are a scalable outcome of Pan-Arctic Options with user-defined granularity over time and space to address socioeconomic changes across the Arctic Ocean, applying ship movements, types, sizes, cargos and nationalities objectively.  The invited essay in the NOAA Arctic Report Card 2022 further represents a decision to include maritime ship traffic and the ship-ice hypothesis among the Pan-Arctic indicators of change in the Arctic Ocean with relevance across the growing complex of US Arctic policies. 

     Practical next-steps involving S-AIS data have been introduced with mapping of maritime ship traffic in all Exclusive Economic Zone and High Seas areas north of the Arctic Circle (Figure 3: Pan-Arctic Maritime Ship Traffic) under the law of the sea, to which all Arctic states and Indigenous Peoples Organizations remain committed.  The convergent outcome of Pan-Arctic Options is holistic integration with natural sciences, social sciences and Indigenous knowledge (Figure 4: Holistic Integration Mapping), all of which reveal patterns, trends and processes (albeit with different methods) that become the bases for informed decisions, ultimately at personal-to-planetary levels for the benefit of all on Earth across generations.
